title: Monitor Calibration with X-Rite i1Display Pro
summary: Photographer Peter Hurley and Josh from X-Rite demonstrate the step-by-step process of calibrating an iMac monitor using the i1Display Pro and i1Profiler software in Advanced mode to ensure color accuracy for photography.

steps.action: Launch i1Profiler software, select 'Advanced' User Mode, and click 'Profiling' under Display.
Select the display technology type. Choose 'CCFL' for older iMacs or 'White LED'/'Wide Gamut' for newer screens.
Set White Point to 'CIE Illuminant D65', the standard for the photo industry.
Set Luminance to '120 cd/m²' for desktops (recommended 90 cd/m² for laptops) to avoid over-saturation.
Keep default Profile Settings (Gamma 2.2, Standard Tone Response Curve).
Select Patch Set size. A larger patch set (e.g., Medium or Large) provides more accuracy but takes longer.
Click 'Start Measurement'. Follow prompts to place the i1Display Pro device on the screen to read color patches.
Name the profile (e.g., based on environment) and set a reminder interval (e.g., 4 weeks). Click 'Create and save profile'.
Use the 'Before' and 'After' toggle to verify the calibration results.

key_takeaways: Calibrate monitors every 4 weeks to maintain accuracy.
Use D65 White Point and 120 cd/m² Luminance for standard photography editing environments.
Avoid using continuous ambient light monitoring if lighting conditions change frequently; instead, control the room lighting manually.
Accurate monitor calibration is essential before editing to ensure prints and web display look correct.
